sen.j: 竹御所（たけのごしょ、建仁2年（1202年） - 天福 (日本)2年7月27日 (旧暦)（1234年8月23日））は、鎌倉時代初期の女性。
sen.e: TAKE no Gosho (1202- August 23, 1234) was a woman in the early Kamakura period.
TAKE no Gosho (1202- August 23, 1234) was a woman in the early Kamakura period.
TAKE no Gosho (1202- August 23, 1234) was a woman in the early Kamakura period.

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府第二代征夷大将軍源頼家の娘。
sen.e: She was the daughter of MINAMOTO no Yoriie, who was the second generation conquest barbarian general of the Kamakura Shogunate.
She was a daughter of MINAMOTO no Yoriie, who was the second seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Kamakura bakufu.
sen.cmt: 「娘」は一人とは限りません。「第2代征夷大将軍」の訳出が不適切です。
sen.e: She was a daughter of MINAMOTO no Yoriie, who was the second seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Kamakura bakufu.
The rank name in record under ordinance was Mariko.
Her name recorded in the Iki (court rank diploma) was Mariko.
sen.cmt: 「位記」の訳が分かりにくかったので修正しました。
sen.e: Her name recorded in the Iki (court rank diploma) was Mariko.

sen.j: 母は『尊卑分脈』で源義仲の娘とされる。
sen.e: Though her mother is considered to be the daughter of MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka according to "Sompi Bunmyaku" (Bloodlines of Noble and Base).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Her mother is considered to be a daughter of MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka, according to "Sompi Bunmyaku" (Bloodlines of Noble and Base).
sen.cmt: これでは主節が存在しないことになります。
sen.e: Her mother is considered to be a daughter of MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka, according to "Sompi Bunmyaku" (Bloodlines of Noble and Base).

sen.j: しかし、竹の御所と呼ばれた鞠子の邸は比企ヶ谷の比企氏の邸跡である事から、母は比企能員の娘若狭局と考えられる。
sen.e: But from the fact that Mariko's house, which was called the Palace of Bamboo, was located on the house site of HIKI family in Hiki Valley, her mother was considered to be the daughter WAKASA no Tsubone of Yoshikazu HIKI.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: However, given the fact that Mariko's residence, which was called the Palace of Bamboo, was located on the former estate of the Hiki family in the Hikigatani Valley, her mother was considered to be WAKASA no Tsubone, a daughter of Yoshikazu HIKI.
sen.cmt: 英語として不自然な表現を修正しました。家名は頭文字のみ大文字で表記します。
sen.e: However, given the fact that Mariko's residence, which was called the Palace of Bamboo, was located on the former estate of the Hiki family in the Hikigatani Valley, her mother was considered to be WAKASA no Tsubone, a daughter of Yoshikazu HIKI.

sen.j: 父頼家が北条氏によって暗殺された後、兄の公暁と共に叔父である源実朝の猶子となる。
sen.e: After her father Yoriie was assassinated by HOJO, she and her elder brother Kugyo became adopted children of their uncle MINAMOTO no Sanetomo.
After her father Yoriie was assassinated by the Hojo clan, she and her elder brother Kugyo were adopted by their uncle MINAMOTO no Sanetomo.
sen.cmt: 直訳では不自然な英文になります。
sen.e: After her father Yoriie was assassinated by the Hojo clan, she and her elder brother Kugyo were adopted by their uncle MINAMOTO no Sanetomo.

sen.j: 他の頼家の子が、幕府の政争の中で次々に非業の死を遂げていく中で、祖母である北条政子の庇護のもとにあり女子であった竹御所はそれに巻き込まれることを免れた。
sen.e: While the other children of Yoriie suffered from severe death one after another in the political strife of the shogunate, TAKE no Gosho, who was a girl sheltered and protected under her grandmother Masako HOJO, escaped from dragged into the strife.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: While the other children of Yoriie suffered a violent death one after another in the political strife within the shogunate, TAKE no Gosho, who was a girl protected by her grandmother Masako HOJO, escaped from being dragged into the strife.
sen.cmt: 過去分詞draggedは前置詞fromの目的語にはなりません。
sen.e: While the other children of Yoriie suffered a violent death one after another in the political strife within the shogunate, TAKE no Gosho, who was a girl protected by her grandmother Masako HOJO, escaped from being dragged into the strife.

sen.j: 政子死去後、その実質的な後継者となる。
sen.e: After Masako died, she became the substantial successor.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: After Masako died, she became the substantial successor.
After Masako died, she became the substantial successor.

sen.j: 幕府関係者の中で唯一頼朝の血筋を引く生き残りである竹御所は幕府の権威の象徴として、御家人の尊敬を集め、彼らをまとめる役目を果たした。
sen.e: Among the people related to the shogunate, as the only remaining survivor who was blood-tied to Yoriie, TAKE no Gosho was a symbol of the authority of the shogunate, gathered the family's respect, and played the role to bringing them together.

As the only remaining survivor who was blood-tied to Yoriie among all the people related to the shogunate, TAKE no Gosho was respected by gokenin (immediate vasals of the shogunate)as a symbol of the authority of the shogunate, and played the role of bringing them together.
sen.cmt: 原文により忠実な訳となるよう語順を変更しました。「御家人」の訳出は用語集を参照しました。「～の役目を果たす」はplay the role of～ing。
sen.e: As the only remaining survivor who was blood-tied to Yoriie among all the people related to the shogunate, TAKE no Gosho was respected by gokenin (immediate vasals of the shogunate)as a symbol of the authority of the shogunate, and played the role of bringing them together.

sen.j: 寛喜2年（1230年）、28歳で13歳の第4代征夷大将軍藤原頼経に嫁ぐ。
sen.e: In 1230, she at the age of 28 married the fourth generation conquest barbarian general martial FUJIWARA no Yoritsune who was 13 years old.
In 1230, at the age of 28 she married the fourth seii taishogun FUJIWARA no Yoritsune who was 13 years old.
In 1230, at the age of 28 she married the fourth seii taishogun FUJIWARA no Yoritsune who was 13 years old.

sen.j: 夫婦仲は円満であったと伝えられる。
sen.e: It is said that the married couple relations were harmonious.
It is said that the couple got along well together.
sen.cmt: 直訳では英文として意味をなしません。
sen.e: It is said that the couple got along well together.

sen.j: その4年後に妊り、頼朝の血を引く将軍後継者誕生の期待を周囲に抱かせる。
sen.e: Four years, she was pregnant and people in the surroundings were expecting the birth of the successor to the general, who would have been blood-tied to Yoritomo.
Four years after the marriage, she got pregnant and people around her were expecting the birth of a successor to the general, who would be blood-tied to Yoritomo.
sen.cmt: 何の4年後なのかを明記します。
sen.e: Four years after the marriage, she got pregnant and people around her were expecting the birth of a successor to the general, who would be blood-tied to Yoritomo.

sen.j: しかし、難産の末、男子を死産、竹御所本人も33歳で死去。
sen.e: However, the boy was a stillbirth after the hard delivery, and TAKE no Gosho herself also died at the age of 33.
However, she lost her unborn boy after the hard delivery, and she herself also died at the age of 33.
sen.cmt: 竹御所を主語にしてまとめた方がすっきりします。
sen.e: However, she lost her unborn boy after the hard delivery, and she herself also died at the age of 33.

sen.j: 竹御所の死により源頼朝の血筋は完全に断絶した。
sen.e: With the death of TAKE no Gosho, the blood descent of MINAMOTO no Yoritomo was completely ruptured.
With the death of TAKE no Gosho, the bloodline originated in MINAMOTO no Yoritomo was completely ruptured.
With the death of TAKE no Gosho, the bloodline originated in MINAMOTO no Yoritomo was completely ruptured.

sen.j: 当時の初産としては高齢であり、出産に当たり竹御所本人も死を覚悟していたとも言われる。
sen.e: Since she was considered to be too old to have the first childbirth at that time, it is said that TAKE no Gosho herself was also prepared for the risk of death when giving birth.
Since she was considered to be too old to have the first childbirth at that time, it is said that TAKE no Gosho herself was also prepared for the risk of death when giving birth.
Since she was considered to be too old to have the first childbirth at that time, it is said that TAKE no Gosho herself was also prepared for the risk of death when giving birth.

sen.j: 藤原定家の日記である『明月記』には、竹御所死去の報がもたらされると、頼朝の血筋が断絶したことによる鎌倉武士たちの動揺は激しく、京都にあった幕府御家人はこぞって鎌倉に下ったと記されている。
sen.e: According to the record in FUJIWARA no Sadaie's diary "Meigetsuki" (Chronicle of the Bright Moon), when the news of TAKE no Gosho broke out, the Kamakura samurais were so drastically shocked upon hearing the blood descent of Yoritomo being ruptured that, the shogunate family members in Kyoto all descended to Kamakura in a body.

According to the record in FUJIWARA no Sadaie's diary "Meigetsuki" (Chronicle of the Bright Moon), when the news of the death of TAKE no Gosho broke out, the Kamakura samurais were so much shocked upon hearing the bloodline of Yoritomo ruptured that, gokenin in Kyoto all descended to Kamakura in a body.

According to the record in FUJIWARA no Sadaie's diary "Meigetsuki" (Chronicle of the Bright Moon), when the news of the death of TAKE no Gosho broke out, the Kamakura samurais were so much shocked upon hearing the bloodline of Yoritomo ruptured that, gokenin in Kyoto all descended to Kamakura in a body.

sen.j: 吾妻鏡は嘉禎元年七月二十七日条に竹御所の喪に服した姫のことを記載している。
sen.e: In the Japanese history book "Azuma Kagami" (The Mirror of the East), it was recorded that, on July 27, 1235, some girls were serving the mourning of TAKE no Gosho.
In the Japanese history book "Azuma Kagami" (The Mirror of the East), it was recorded that, on July 27, 1235, some princesses were serving the mourning of TAKE no Gosho.
In the Japanese history book "Azuma Kagami" (The Mirror of the East), it was recorded that, on July 27, 1235, some princesses were serving the mourning of TAKE no Gosho.

sen.j: 竹御所の墓は比企氏一族の菩提寺である妙本寺にある。
sen.e: The grave of TAKE no Gosho was in Myohon-ji Temple, which was HIKI clan's family temple.
The grave of TAKE no Gosho was in the Myohon-ji Temple, which was Hiki clan's family temple.
